<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 688, 532]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 565, 170, 581]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 834, 182]]<|/det|>
An Olympic diver stands on a platform above a pool of water, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 193, 777, 477]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 491, 591, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 920, 573]]<|/det|>
When the diver is on the platform his centre of gravity is a vertical height of \(9.0 \text{m}\) above the surface of the water. The diver jumps from the platform with a velocity of \(5.9 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) to the horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 586, 378, 603]]<|/det|>
Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 617, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
When the diver hits the surface of the water, his centre of gravity is a vertical height of \(1.2 \text{m}\) above the surface of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 663, 794, 680]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed of the diver at the instant he hits the surface of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 910, 920, 927]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 910, 920, 927]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 564, 89]]<|/det|>
The diver in **(b)** enters the water and decelerates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 180, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Describe and explain the variation of the viscous drag force acting on the diver in the water as he moves downwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 242, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 272, 181, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 272, 897, 291]]<|/det|>
The diver has a volume of \(7.5 \times 10^{-2} \text{m}^3\). The density of the water is \(1.0 \times 10^3 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 303, 871, 320]]<|/det|>
Show that the upthrust acting on the diver when he is entirely underwater is \(740 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 473, 180, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 473, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
At a particular instant when the diver is entirely underwater his horizontal velocity is zero. The viscous drag force acting on him at this instant is \(950 \text{N}\) vertically upwards. The diver has mass \(78 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 535, 774, 552]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude and direction of the acceleration of the diver.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 848, 920, 866]]<|/det|>

<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A thin metal wire X, of diameter \(1.2 \times 10^{- 3} \text{m}\), is used to suspend a model planet, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 376, 591, 395]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 390, 89]]<|/det|>
The strain in X is \(5.4 \times 10^{- 3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 181, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 101, 808, 121]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... N [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 658, 920, 678]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 689, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
Wire X is replaced by a new wire, Y, with the same original length and diameter but double the Young modulus of X. Wire Y also obeys Hooke's law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 736, 808, 755]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.2, draw a line representing the variation with strain of the stress for Y.

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 541, 89]]<|/det|>
A nucleus P undergoes \(\alpha \)-decay to form nucleus Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 465, 121]]<|/det|>
Complete the equation for this decay.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 133, 648, 168]]<|/det|>
\[^{215}_{84}\mathbf{P}\longrightarrow \overrightarrow{\mathbf{Q}} +\overrightarrow{\mathbf{\Lambda}}\alpha\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 178, 146, 197]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 179, 183, 197]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 303, 181, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 303, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
Before the decay, nucleus P has a speed of \(3.2 \times 10^{5} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\). After the decay, nucleus Q is stationary.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 349, 660, 368]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed of the alpha particle after the decay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 580, 920, 599]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = ................................................. $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<mark>[Total: 6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
By reference to the direction of propagation of energy, state what is meant by a transverse wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 147, 918, 165]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 146, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 920, 215]]<|/det|>
A space telescope is designed to detect electromagnetic radiation with wavelengths in the range \(12 \mu \text{m}\) to \(28 \mu \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 226, 702, 244]]<|/det|>
State the region of the electromagnetic spectrum for this radiation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 257, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 288, 146, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
A detector on another space telescope detects an electromagnetic wave. The signal from the detector is transmitted to Earth and displayed on an oscilloscope as shown in Fig. 5.1. The frequency of the signal displayed on the oscilloscope is equal to the frequency of the detected electromagnetic wave.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 361, 781, 667]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 681, 532, 700]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 712, 675, 730]]<|/det|>
The time-base setting on the oscilloscope is \(5.0 \times 10^{-15} \text{s} \text{cm}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 744, 685, 761]]<|/det|>
Calculate the wavelength of the detected electromagnetic wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[468, 893, 920, 911]]<|/det|>
<form>wavelength = .................................................... m [3]

<mark>[Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Coherent visible light of a single frequency is incident normally on a double slit. This produces a pattern of bright and dark interference fringes on a screen, as illustrated in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 112, 892, 352]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 363, 591, 382]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 394, 411, 413]]<|/det|>
There are seven bright fringes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 425, 181, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 425, 791, 444]]<|/det|>
Explain how the pattern of bright and dark interference fringes is formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 612, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 642, 181, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 641, 920, 675]]<|/det|>
The distance between the centres of bright fringe X and bright fringe Y in the pattern is 10.2 mm. The slit spacing is 1.2 mm. The distance from the slits to the screen is 3.1 m.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 688, 663, 706]]<|/det|>
Calculate the wavelength of the light incident on the slits.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 884, 920, 902]]<|/det|>
<form>wavelength = .................................................... m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 181, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 777, 91]]<|/det|>
The light is replaced by different visible light with a shorter wavelength.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 866, 121]]<|/det|>
State how the new fringe separation will compare to the original fringe separation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 164, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 163, 767, 183]]<|/det|>
A stationary wave is formed on a stretched string AB, as shown in Fig. 6.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 191, 833, 323]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 333, 534, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 365, 165, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>P,</label>
